ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We traced the development of sociolinguistics from its founding in the 1960s to recent work, and studied the three "waves" of sociolinguistics. This meant that we read a lot of real linguistics papers and talked about research methodology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course material is incredibly interesting. Because of the small class size and discussion-based structure, there is always opportunity to ask questions or contribute to the class dialogue. The homework sets and reflection tasks are designed to encourage you to connect the material to your own life. I didn't feel that the class had any notably weaknesses. Maybe the technology week could have been moved closer to the end of the semester, around the time when we started thinking about the final project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.  Although it is probably helpful to have been introduced to some concepts in linguistics, you certainly do not have to have taken a linguistic course to appreciate the studies covered in class, especially because Professor Burns elaborates on them with examples in non-academic contexts. If you are at all interested in how linguistic variation arises, how linguistic variation indexes social meaning, language and gender, linguistic profiling, code-switching, etc., you should take this course.
Yes! This course is fascinating and not taught often at Yale, so if you have the opportunity to take it, definitely do so.

The content you cover in this class is super interesting, and it's great to learn about what linguistic research actually looks like. I would highly recommend this class, except that the work is VERY backloaded. I would expect to spend a LOT of time working on your final project.
